title: Lobste.rs domain renewal outage
description:
Lobsters was down ~4 hours, until a few minutes ago, because our domain name expired. It‚Äôs now renewed. I woke up to the outage so I‚Äôm still a bit discombobulated, but here‚Äôs quick notes explaining the situation.

Our registrar had previously comped domain renewals and emails about this year‚Äôs renewal looked like it was proceeding as normal, but apparently that didn‚Äôt happen. I put our backup domain lobsters.dev up. (I registered lobsters.dev years ago because I was nervous about a country code domain with the only registrar I could find in a foreign country whose language I don‚Äôt speak.)

So I pulled up the customer control panel and could view an invoice, but the payment system was down and I was unable to pay the outstanding invoice. I emailed support and my contact there. About 15 minutes later the invoice status changed to ‚ÄòCancelled‚Äô (like previous years) and the domain showed as renewed to 2024. A few minutes later as DNS propagated, the domain started resolving.

I haven‚Äôt yet heard back from the registrar and will post comments below when I do. I‚Äôd appreciate any suggestions on how to better handle this potential failure mode.

Happy lobstering,

  • Peter
description_plain:
Lobsters was down ~4 hours, until a few minutes ago, because our domain name expired. It's now renewed. I woke up to the outage so I'm still a bit discombobulated, but here's quick notes explaining the situation.

Our registrar had previously comped domain renewals and emails about this year's renewal looked like it was proceeding as normal, but apparently that didn't happen. I put our [backup domain lobsters.dev](https://lobsters.dev) up. (I registered lobsters.dev years ago because I was nervous about a country code domain with the only registrar I could find in a foreign country whose language I don't speak.)

So I pulled up the customer control panel and could view an invoice, but the payment system was down and I was unable to pay the outstanding invoice. I emailed support and my contact there. About 15 minutes later the invoice status changed to 'Cancelled' (like previous years) and the domain showed as renewed to 2024. A few minutes later as DNS propagated, the domain started resolving.

I haven't yet heard back from the registrar and will post comments below when I do. I'd appreciate any suggestions on how to better handle this potential failure mode.

Happy lobstering,

- Peter

submitter_user.about: Hi, I'm [Peter Bhat Harkins](https://malaprop.org), a programmer and entrepreneur from Chicago. From June 2014 to winter of 2015 I typically posted a dozen stories per day to [help](https://lobste.rs/s/9pm09z/what_is_on_topic_what_is_not/comments/nie0yn#c_nie0yn) the site reach a critical mass of regular visitors. In October 2017 I became the site administrator after the site creator @jcs stepped down. * Please don‚Äôt message me for an invitation if we're complete strangers; check the user list for someone you know or ask [in chat](https://lobste.rs/chat). * Submit a [`meta`](https://lobste.rs/t/meta) post for feature requests (including new tags) to let the community discuss. Bug reports and "is this a bug?" should go to [the issue tracker](https://github.com/lobsters/lobsters/issues). * [Message me](https://lobste.rs/messages?to=pushcx) for administrative and moderator things. I don't see everything and I gotta sleep sometime. * E-mail my first name @malaprop.org regarding site security or if you can't log in to message me. If I've posted or commented about something here or in the chat room, I'd almost certainly love to talk more about it.

Has anyone found a robust way to test interactive CLI programs?
description: For testing non-interactive commands there are things like bats, but for things that require interactivity the common recommendation is expect. In my experience expect is pretty brittle. Let‚Äôs say you‚Äôve already cut down the number of things you‚Äôre trying to test interactively in the first place, but you‚Äôre left with a chunk of functionality that still does need to be tested. What is standard practice in this kind of situation?
description_plain: For testing non-interactive commands there are things like `bats`, but for things that require interactivity the common recommendation is `expect`. In my experience `expect` is pretty brittle. Let's say you've already cut down the number of things you're trying to test interactively in the first place, but you're left with a chunk of functionality that still does need to be tested. What is standard practice in this kind of situation?
